title-group.article-title: Carbon nanotube–metal oxide composite electrodes for secondary lithium-based batteries

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Electrical Engineering, University at Buffalo (SUNY), USA
2Department of Chemistry, University at Buffalo (SUNY), USA
3Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University at Buffalo (SUNY), USA
4Department of Biomedical Engineering, University at Buffalo (SUNY), USA

author-notes.corresp: Amy C Marschilok, Department of Electrical Engineering, University at Buffalo (SUNY), Buffalo, New York 14260, USA. Email: acm@buffalo.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Preparation and electrochemical evaluation of battery cathodes made from carbon nanotube substrates and lithium trivanadate (LiV3O8) are reported in this study. Our carbon nanotube substrate–LiV3O8 (CNT-SI) cathodes displayed good rate capability (>140 mAh/g on 1C discharge) and improved capacity retention (>280 mAh/g after 30 cycles at C/20) when utilized in lithium-based batteries. The use of the CNT-SI composite where the electrodes are comprised of a carbon nanotube substrate and active material with no addition of binder, additional carbon additives, and without a foil backing provides the opportunity for a 25% increase in the percentage of active mass and a 36% reduction in the total electrode mass. These benefits demonstrate that considering electrode configuration as well as active material is a key strategic approach to enhance battery energy density.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Vanadium oxides continue to attract significant scientific interest due to their potential as energy storage materials. Vanadium oxides have high theoretical energy densities, primarily due to the variable formal oxidation states (II–V) of vanadium cations.1–3 In battery terms, vanadium oxides can host lithium ions for reversible ion insertion and provide high capacities on discharge in excess of 300 mAh/g.4–10

A candidate active material of interest for secondary lithium-based batteries is lithium trivanadate, LiV3O8, with a high theoretical capacity of 372 mAh/g. Lithium trivanadate (LiV3O8) can be synthesized in a solid-state process by mixing lithium carbonate and vanadium pentoxide in air at 680°C.11–13 An alternative synthesis is a low-temperature approach utilizing the sol–gel method.13–15 The sol–gel synthesis typically produces materials of a smaller particle size, providing more facile access for Li+ diffusion. The sol–gel preparation route for LiV3O8 has shown a higher initial capacity relative to the solid-state preparation route (300 versus 180 mAh/g).13 However, capacity fade upon cycling13 and limited rate capability16 have also been observed with sol–gel-prepared LiV3O8 when used in a coated foil electrode design.

We recently introduced a new design strategy for the preparation of novel carbon nanotube substrate–metal oxide (CNTS–MxOy) composite cathodes, establishing the potential for 20–60% increases in cathode specific capacity using our composite electrode strategy.17 Conventional battery cathodes are prepared from physical mixtures of conductive additives (carbon), binders (polymer), and active material particles which are coated onto current collectors (metal foils), where each passive component has a distinct and specific function. The current collector provides structural support and a continuous conductive pathway. The binder maintains physical adhesion throughout the composite, and the conductive additives establish an interconnected conduction network via percolation. Since the capacity and energy density of a conventional battery is dictated largely by the quantity of active material within the cathode, minimizing the amount of passive material in the cathode is desirable.

We successfully replaced the three passive components (conductive additive, binder, and current collector) with a single multifunctional three-dimensional carbon-based substrate (CNTS). For their use in battery electrodes, carbon nanotubes offer the advantages of lightweight, high conductivity,18,19 a wide range of reduction and oxidation tolerances, and a high degree of chemical resistance.20 The CNTS provided all the necessary properties of conventional conductive additives, binders, and current collectors, with significantly lower weight than the conventionally used materials.

Our CNTS–MxOy composite strategy is translatable for any active material which can be prepared using a sol–gel synthesis.21 Here, we describe the extension of our novel CNTS–MxOy composite strategy from V2O5 to LiV3O8 based cathodes. Preparation and electrochemical evaluation of battery cathodes prepared using CNTSs with lithium trivanadate (LiV3O8) synthesized from a sol–gel method will be reported herein.

sec.title: Material preparation
sec.p: Lithium vanadium oxide gels with a formula of LiV3O8 were synthesized using a low-temperature sol–gel method described in prior11,12,22 and recent literature.23–25 Lithium hydroxide monohydrate (LiOH·H2O) and vanadium pentoxide (α-V2O5) were used as reagents in aqueous solution. The resulting brown xerogels were then treated in two different methods. The first isolation method, denoted as ‘gel-H,’ involved freeze-drying the gels from the aqueous (H2O) solutions. The second post-synthesis treatment method, denoted as ‘gel-S,’ involved isolation of the solid via centrifugation and washing of the component with organic solvent (acetone). Both gel-H and gel-S solids were dried in vacuo at 110°C. The samples were then subjected to heat treatment at 300°C for 10 h.

sec.title: Material characterization
sec.p: LiV3O8 samples were characterized by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), simultaneous thermogravimetric analysis/differential scanning calorimetry (TGA/DSC), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller surface area analysis (BET), and light scattering based particle size analysis. A Thermo Scientific ICAP 6300 radial ICP-OES was used for quantitative Li and V analysis. A TA Instruments Q600 was used for TGA/DSC. A Rigaku Ultima IV XRD was used with Cu-Kα radiation and Bragg–Brentano focusing geometry. MDI JADE version 8.5.3 software with ICDD and NIST databases was used for search–match analysis. SEM and EDS data were collected using a Hitachi S-800. A Micromeritics Tristar was used for BET measurement by N2 adsorption. A Horiba LA950-V2 was used for particle size analysis, where samples were dispersed in water during the particle size measurement.

sec.title: Electrode preparation
sec.p: Acid-treated CNTSs from Nanocomp Technologies were used as the substrates. The lithium vanadate precursor gel (before isolation as a solid) was delivered directly as a liquid to the CNTS. This composite fabrication process has been termed ‘substrate integration (SI),’ as the active material is integrated directly with the CNTS.17 After drying in vacuo at 110°C, the CNTS–LiV3O8 composites were heat treated for 10 h at 300°C. The abbreviation ‘CNT-SI’ is used to describe the CNTS–LiV3O8 composites throughout this article.

sec.title: Electrochemical test
sec.p: Electrolyte of 1 M lithium hexafluorophosphate in a 30:70 mixture of ethylene carbonate : dimethyl carbonate was used for all electrochemical testing. Cyclic voltammetry data were collected at room temperature using a three-electrode assembly, with lithium metal reference and auxiliary electrodes. The cyclic voltammetry program was set to scan at 0.01 mV/s between voltage limits of 3.8 and 1.7 V.

Galvanostatic discharge and discharge–charge testing was conducted at 30°C using a two-electrode assembly, with lithium metal anodes. C-rates were determined assuming a theoretical capacity of 300 mAh/g.25 First, a galvanostatic intermittent titration test (GITT) type scheme was used. The cells were discharged using a current rate equal to C/2 for 10 min followed by a 60 min rest at open circuit potential.

Next, a cycle life test was conducted where the test cells were discharged to 2.0 V at a current rate equal to C/20 to the desired voltage of 2.0, 2.4, or 2.5 V and then charged at a current rate equal to C/10 to 3.8 V. After the initial first discharge, the cells entered a series of charge–discharge cycles. Test cells were charged to 3.8 V at a current rate equal to C/10, held at the high potential for 2 h, and discharged at a rate of C/5. This process was repeated for 100 discharge–charge cycles.

A third test was designed to assess the rate capability. In this study, the cells were discharged at a C/20 rate for three discharge–charge cycles, then C/5 for five discharge–charge cycles, C/2 for five discharge–charge cycles, and 1C for five discharge–charge cycles. The cells then went through the opposite order of C-rate discharge–charge cycles.

sec.title: Structure of lithium vanadate (LiV3O8)
sec.p:
Lithium vanadate with the molecular formula Li1+xV3O8 (x = 0–0.2) crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group P21/m.26 LiV3O8 is composed of edge and corner-sharing VO4 octahedra and VO5 distorted trigonal bipyramids, with Li+ occupying the interlayer positions. Since lithium vanadate consists of V3O8 layers stacked perpendicular to the b–c plane (Figure 1), d1 0 0 is considered the interlayer spacing. The major peak at 2Θ ∼ 14° corresponds to the (1 0 0) plane.24 Figure 1.
Structure of Li0.97V3O8 (PDF#97-005-5717).

sec.title: Material preparation and characterization
sec.p:
To validate that our synthesis process produced the desired LiV3O8 products, various techniques were used to characterize the powders. XRD patterns were compared with reference patterns for LiV3O8 in addition to other compounds which could be produced using a related synthesis method (α-V2O5, Li0.3V2O5, Li2CO3, etc.). Our material was consistent with a reference pattern for Li0.97V3O8 (PDF#97-005-5717). Crystallite size and interlayer spacing were determined using the Scherrer equation and Bragg’s law, respectively (Table 1). Table 1.
XRD data for the (1 0 0) peak
Sample ID d-Spacing (Å) Crystallite size (nm)
Gel-H 6.32 24
Gel-S 6.34 22
XRD: X-ray diffraction.

SEM images were acquired at varying magnifications. All samples showed a consistent branched morphology and the representative images are shown (Figure 2). In general, the particle size of the gel-H samples was larger by SEM relative to the particle size of the gel-S samples. The gel-H samples had typical BET surface areas of 1.2 m2/g while the gel-S had typical surface areas of 4.9 m2/g, consistent with the SEM images. Thus, the use of organic solvent allowed isolation of a higher surface area LiV3O8 xerogel. Figure 2.
Scanning electron micrograph for LiV3O8: (a) gel-H, 1000 × magnification; (b) gel-H, 5000 × magnification; (c) gel-S, 1000 × magnification; and (d) gel-S, 5000 × magnification.

TGA was used to determine the water content for the lithium vanadium oxide material. ICP-OES was used to quantitatively determine the lithium and vanadium contents for each sample. Based on TGA and ICP-OES results, the formulas were assigned as Li0.96V3O8·0.04 H2O and Li1.09V3O8·0.04 H2O for the gel-S and gel-H samples, respectively. For simplicity, the generalized nomenclature LiV3O8 is used elsewhere throughout this article.

sec.title: Composite characterization
sec.p:
To validate that lithium vanadium oxide (LiV3O8) was fabricated in the presence of the CNTSs using the SI composite fabrication method discussed above, the CNTS-SI composite electrodes were characterized using XRD (Figure 3). XRD patterns were compared with the reference patterns for LiV3O8 in addition to other compounds which could be produced using this synthesis method (α-V2O5, Li0.3V2O5, Li2CO3). XRD data were also collected on uncoated CNTS. Figure 3.
XRD patterns for: (a) CNT-SI composite; (b) gel-H; and (c) CNTS with no gel. XRD: X-ray diffraction; CNT-SI: carbon nanotube substrate–LiV3O8; and CNTS: carbon nanotube substrate. The high-intensity peaks at 2Θ = 39° and 45° indicate the aluminum sample vessel.

The major component of our CNT-SI matched well with our gel-H LiV3O8 sample and a reference pattern for Li0.97V3O8 (PDF#97-005-5717), indicating that LiV3O8 was the major vanadium oxide phase formed using our composite fabrication method. Some small additional peaks not assigned to LiV3O8 were evident in the CNT-SI sample, most clearly at 2Θ = 9.6°. This indicated formation of a minor second phase whose major peaks were consistent with Li0.3V2O5 (PDF#97-016-6482). Prior literature has indicated that in the presence of carbon at higher temperatures, lithium trivanadate may undergo carbo-reduction,27 thus our results reflect the previous reports.

SEM images were taken to study how the lithium vanadium oxide integrates with the CNTS in the CNTS-SI composite. For comparative purposes, uncoated CNTS were also imaged (Figure 4(a) and (b)). The images showed clear integration of the LiV3O8 material throughout the thickness of the CNTS (Figure 4(c) and (d)). These SEM results were consistent with our previously reported CNT-SI composites based on V2O5.17 Figure 4.
Scanning electron micrographs at 5000 × magnification: (a) uncoated CNTS, secondary electron imaging mode; (b) uncoated CNTS, backscatter imaging mode; (c) CNT-SI, secondary electron imaging mode; and (d) CNT-SI, backscatter imaging mode. CNTS: carbon nanotube substrate; CNT-SI: carbon nanotube substrate–LiV3O8.

sec.title: Electrochemical evaluation
sec.p:
Cyclic voltammetry is a useful tool to assess reversibility of the reduction–oxidation (discharge–charge process). Previous cyclic voltammetry studies on coated foil and pressed pellet LiV3O8 electrodes have been conducted at scan rates ranging from 0.1–2.0 mV/s.28,29 The prior data show quasi-reversible behavior, with multiple redox waves evident in the voltage window of 3.5–2.0 V versus lithium. Cyclic voltammetry data were collected for the CNT-SI composite electrodes at a scan rate of 0.01 mV/s (Figure 5). Improved resolution of the multiple redox peaks was achieved compared to the previous reports, likely due to the slow scan rate used for the cyclic voltammetry test. The overall appearance of our voltammogram is reminiscent of the differential capacity previously presented for coated foil electrodes fabricated from LiV3O8 xerogel heat treated at 350°C.14 Figure 5.
Cyclic voltammogram for three electrode cells containing CNT-SI composite electrodes. CNT-SI: carbon nanotube substrate–LiV3O8.

A GITT-type scheme was used to investigate the polarization of the CNT-SI cathodes. GITT involves intermittent imposition of a fixed current over a fixed time interval, followed by removal of the applied current, allowing the voltage of the cell to recover.30 This technique allows the polarization of the cell to be observed as a function of discharge.31,32 Over the course of the electrochemical reduction of Li1+xV3O8, the polarization was initially higher in the region of x = 0.5, then lower in the region 0.5 < x ≤ 1.6, then larger at higher states of discharge (x > 1.6) (Figure 6). Figure 6.
Voltage versus electron equivalents for GITT-type discharge of two electrode containing CNT-SI composite electrodes. GITT: galvanostatic intermittent titration test; CNT-SI: carbon nanotube substrate–LiV3O8.

Previous reports have noted the steep potential drop in the discharge curve at x < 0.5, followed by a region where the difference between the loaded potential and open circuit voltage (OCV) was small until x = 1.5.33 With further discharge, beyond x = 1.5, the difference between loaded voltage and OCV became larger. This was attributed to smaller diffusivity of Li+ for the Li1+xV3O8 material at that level of reduction. Additional reports have noted variation in the onset point of the higher level of polarization where x = 1.5 or 2.0.34–36 The variation in the onset voltage of the larger polarization stage was attributed to Li+ ion concentration gradients in the material. Slow Li+ ion diffusion in the highly discharged material can result in a layer of more highly concentrated Li+ near the surface of the material, resulting in the increased polarization. Thus, the changes in polarization as a function of discharge can be explained by considering the structural changes in Li1+xV3O8 as a function of lithium insertion (x-value) as well as the Li+ ion concentration gradients in the solid. Our data are consistent with previous reports.

Representative voltage curves for the third discharge cycle of lithium anode cells with CNT-SI composite electrodes are shown (Figure 7). The voltage curve of LixV3O8 is characterized by multiple voltage plateaus. The plateaus in this experiment are noted to be at ∼3.4, ∼2.7, ∼2.5, and ∼2.2 V. Similar voltage plateaus have been previously observed for LixV3O8 electrodes fabricated using coated metal foil electrodes.13 Thus, while the electrode fabrication method used here was different, the overall voltage behavior of the active material was the same as previously observed. The voltage window under which secondary battery cathode materials such as LiV3O8 are utilized can play a critical role in their capacity retention on multiple discharge–charge cycling.13,14 Test cells containing CNT-SI composite electrodes were cycled for 100 cycles using a current equal to C/10 charge and C/5 discharge. A consistent upper voltage limit of 3.7 V was used during charge, while three different lower voltage limits of 2.0, 2.4, and 2.5 V were evaluated for different groups of cells. The cells discharged to 2.0 V delivered capacities of 280 mAh/g of active material, while the cells discharged to 2.4 and 2.5 V delivered capacities of 210 and 160 mAh/g, respectively (Figure 7). Figure 7.
Representative cycle 3 data – voltage test for two electrode cells containing CNT-SI composite electrodes. CNT-SI: carbon nanotube substrate–LiV3O8.

All the cells cycled effectively such that at cycle 100, the cells were providing discharge capacities >130 mAh/g and discharge energies >390 mWh/g (Figure 8). Most notable is that the capacity fade is lower for the cells discharged to 2.4 and 2.5 V compared to the cells discharged to 2.0 V. If the delivered capacity for the cells is compared, the cells discharged to 2.4 and 2.5 V start to outperform the 2.0 V cell by about the 80th cycle (Figure 8(a)). When specific energy is considered, the 2.4 and 2.5 V cells begin to outperform the 2.0 V cells by the 70th cycle due to their higher average loaded voltage (Figure 8(b)). Thus, the cells discharged to 2.4 and 2.5 V displayed significantly improved capacity retention relative to the cells discharged to 2.0 V, as the percentages of cycle 1 capacity retained at cycle 100 were 51%, 79%, and 86% under the 2.0, 2.4, and 2.5 V windows, respectively. Figure 8.
Voltage window cycling test for two electrode cells containing CNT-SI composite electrodes: (a) capacity versus cycle number and (b) energy versus cycle number. CNT-SI: carbon nanotube substrate–LiV3O8.

Investigations on the effect of charge–discharge voltage window compare favorably with published data13. Regarding Li1.1V3O8 specifically, chemical and electrochemical Li+ insertion studies coupled with quantitative analysis have shown partial solubility of Li4–5V3O8 compounds.13 The authors found in some cases that samples with the formula of Li5.0V3O8 showed the dissolution of vanadium, while Li4.0V3O8 samples did not. They conclude this dissolution is due to the presence of V(III), which is partially soluble in electrolyte. On cycle 1 discharge, the average vanadium oxidation state for our LixV3O8 material discharged to 2.0 V was 3.95, and a low solubility would be predicted by the previous report based on the average oxidation state of our material. However, as discussed above, slow Li+ ion diffusion in the highly discharged material can result in concentration gradients within the cathode material,33 resulting in variable Vn+ oxidation states within the material. The greater capacity fade observed during discharge–charge cycling of our CNT-SI electrodes to 2.0 V is consistent with the presence of some V3+ after electrochemical reduction, which has a higher solubility relative to the higher oxidation state (V4+ and V5+) material.

sec.title: Rate capability test
sec.p:
To assess the rate capability of the CNT-SI composite, a test was designed where two electrode cells were discharged at a series of increasing discharge rates, ranging from C/20 to 1 C. The delivered discharge capacities under C/20 exceeded 300 mAh/g on initial cycles. After cycle testing at higher discharge rates, the cells still delivered >280 mAh/g on cycle 30 when discharged again at C/20. Generally, the cells performed well at all rates, and the consistency among the group was good (Figure 9). At a discharge rate of 1C, the cells delivered >140 mAh/g, with no increase in fade observed at higher discharge rates. This verifies that the CNT-SI composite cathode design has an excellent rate capability and can support a high current discharge. Previous reports of cycling LiV3O8-based cells in a 3.7–2.0 V voltage window showed capacities of <150 mAh/g under a C/20 discharge to 30 cycles. Thus, the CNT-SI composite cathodes can provide improved capacity retention and rate capability over conventional electrodes. Figure 9.
Rate capability test for two electrode cells containing CNT-SI composite electrodes.
CNT-SI: carbon nanotube substrate-LiV3O8.
Diamonds are mean values and error bars ±2 SDs. Discharge C-rate = C/20 for cycles 1–3 and 29–31, C/5 for cycles 4–8 and 24–28, C/2 for cycles 9–13 and 19–23, and 1C for cycles 14–18. Charge C-rate = C/10 for all cycles.

sec.title: Comparison of CNT-SI with conventional electrodes
sec.p: In addition to the performance improvements, a significant benefit of the CNT-SI electrodes is that the inactive mass of the electrode is reduced over conventional formulations used to fabricate coated foil electrodes. For example, for an electrode with a loading of 5 mg/cm2 of active material, a conventional electrode would have an active-to-passive component mass ratio of 45–55%. A CNT-SI electrode would have an active-to-passive component mass ratio of 70–30%, providing a 25% increase in the active mass percentage. When the total electrode mass is considered for the foil composite electrode versus the CNT-SI electrode, a 36% mass savings is achieved by the CNT-SI electrode. As the electrode active material loading increases, the contribution of the passive component becomes less significant. However, our CNT-SI approach provides the opportunity for cell-level gravimetric energy density improvement based on the electrode fabrication method, which may have particular benefits in the implementation of high-power designs.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Preparation and electrochemical evaluation of battery cathodes made from CNTSs and lithium trivanadate (LiV3O8) are reported herein. Our CNT-SI cathodes displayed a good rate capability (>140 mAh/g on 1C discharge) and improved capacity retention (>280 mAh/g after 30 cycles at C/20) when utilized in lithium-based batteries. The use of the CNT-SI composite where the electrodes are comprised of a CNTS and active material with no addition of binder, additional carbon additives, and without a foil backing provides the opportunity for a 25% increase in the percentage of active mass and a 36% reduction in the total electrode mass. These benefits demonstrate that considering electrode configuration as well as active material is a key strategic approach to further enhance battery energy density.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received support from the US Department of Energy, Office of Basic Energy Sciences, Division of Materials Science, grant DE-SC0002460, for the materials synthesis methods. The authors also acknowledge Lockheed Martin Corporation for support related to the cathode fabrication methods and electrochemical studies.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors thank Chia-Ying Lee for assistance with SEM and Nanocomp Technologies for supplying CNTSs.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: None declared.
